name: Abwān (near Damietta)
notes: A place of uncertain location but probably identical with the Abwanāt near the village of al-ʿAṭawī in the district of Fāraskūr. See Golb, "The Topography of the Jews of Medieval Egypt," p. 116.

name: Abyssinia (region)
notes: Abyssinia is a region more or less coterminous with modern Ethiopia. I've arbitrarily put the map at Lalibela until the PGP is able to handle regions.

name: Adminna
name_variants: Adiminne, Adiminnen, Adminne, Arminna, Arminne, Armínney
notes: A town located just south of Ibrīm. It is now underwater as a result of the building of the Aswan High Dam.

name: Al-ʿAlawiyya
notes: Unidentified locality near Gush Ḥalav (Jīsh).

name: al-Andalus
notes: Region

name: al-Bannā
notes: Unidentified locality near Fāqūs.

name: al-Gharbiyya (region)
notes: Administrative region

name: al-Maghrib
notes: Region

name: al-Maḥalla
name_variants: al-Maḥalla al-Kubrā, אלמחלה הגדולה, المحلة الكبرى

name: Al-Nastarāwiyya (region)
notes: The strip of land to the north of Lake Burullus.

name: al-Qaṣṣ
notes: Unidentified location thought to be in NW India

name: al-Shām
notes: Region

name: Ashmūn
notes: "Ashmūn" in Geniza documents appears to refer to Ashmūn Ṭannāh, present-day Ashmūn al-Rummān. However this identification is not certain in all cases; there is another locality called Ashmūn in al-Minūfiyya (30.2936, 30.9786).  See Golb, "The Topography of the Jews of Medieval Egypt," p. 118.

name: Bālis
notes: Bālis was abandoned during the medieval period and is absent from many modern maps. For an excellent map of the archaeological site that can be compared/confirmed alongside current satellite imagery, see: Müge Durusu-Tanrıöver, "Ways of Being Hittite: Empire and Borderlands in Late Bronze Age Anatolia and Northern Syria," Studia Orientalia Electronica 9.2 (2021): 18.

name: Bandariyya
notes: According to T-S 10J20.3 (PGPID 5820), located between Tripoli and Alexandria, but can probably be narrowed down more as lying between Benghazi and Tobruk. This location is approximate, based on al-Idrīsī, Nuzhat al-Mushtāq (ed. de Goeje), pp. 137–38, who describes it as lying on a curve or cape from which the coastline turns to face west, but he may intend the next cape over to the east. In T-S 13J15.9 (PGPID 3250), which contains shipping reports, someone sails from Tripoli for Barnīq (Benghazi), but ends up in Bandariyya, i.e., overshoots; someone (else? or the same person?) travels from Tripoli to Bandariyya in 10 days, and (also from Tripoli? or from Bandariyya?) to Alexandria in 20 days, and this is considered making good time. Spelled either Bandariyya (in geniza letters) or Bandāriyya (in al-Idrīsī). MR 11/26/24

name: Bāniyās (Golan)
name_variants: Banias, Pamias, דן, מבצר דן, פאמיס, بانياس

name: Barqa
notes:
The medieval city Barqa (not to be confused with the placename Barqa used for the eastern region, mostly interchangeable with Cyrenaica) was located in al-Marj, now called Old City Marj مدينة المرج القديمة
https://geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?params=32.4983_N_20.8928_E_globe:earth&language=en

name: Buljusūq
notes: On the location of the village, see Tillier and Vanthieghem, Bulǧusūq: Un village du Fayoum sous les Fatimides (IVe-Ve/Xe-XIe siècles), ch. 1.

name: Būra
notes:
"'A city on the seacoast near Damietta, from which come the būrī turbans and the būrī fish (=mullet).' Yāqūt, Muʿjam 1, p. 755; lying midway between Fāraskūr and Damietta."  See Golb, "The Topography of the Jews of Medieval Egypt," pp. 121–22.

Apparently on the site of present-day Kafr al-Baṭṭīkh.

name: Būṣīr
name_variants: Abū Ṣīr, אבוציר, בוציר, ابو صير, بوصير

name: Damietta
name_variants: Dimyāṭ, Dumyāṭ, אי כפתור, קפוטקיא, دمياط

name: Dammūh
name_variants: Dimwa, דמוה, דמוי, דמויה, دير طمويه, طموه, طمويه, Ṭammūh, Ṭamwa, Ṭamwayh
notes: For the location as identical with Ṭammūh/Ṭamwa, see Golb, "Topography," part 1.

name: Damūya
name_variants: Damūya al-Lāhūn, Dimūh, Dimūh al-Lāhūn, هواره عدلان

name: Darb Makīn (street)
notes: Street in Fustat

name: Dhāt al-Ṣafā
notes: See Rapoport and Shahar, Villages of the Fayyūm, 155n204. Modern location: Maʿṣarat Ṣāwī.

name: Erkinun
notes: A town in the frontier zone between Egypt and Nubia. It is located just north of Wādī Ḥalfa on the western bank of the Nile.

name: Ghulayfiqa
notes: The port of Zabīd

name: גומא מזוד
notes: Unidentified location likely in Iraq.

name: Hawwāra
notes: In the 13th century, the port of Hawwāra was known as Qaṣr Aḥmad (Ibn Rushayd al-Sabtī, Riḥla, 6: 5), which became known as Miṣrāta in the 16th century.

name: India
notes: Region

name: Lakhaba
notes: Coordinates are approximate. See Margariti, Aden, 60–63.

name: Land of the Zanj (region)
notes: Bilād al-Zanj refers to the Swahili coast. Until PGP can handle regions, I've arbitrarily set the point at Mombasa.

name: Marīs (region)
notes: One of three Nubian kingdoms that emerged in the aftermath of the collapse of the Kushite kingdom at Meroe. Marīs had its capital at Pachōras (Faras) north of Wādī Ḥalfa. Its region extended from Aswan to the third cataract.

name: Nafūsa
notes: The Nafusa mountains (Jebel Nafusa) or sometimes known simply as Nafusa, is a mountain range in modern-day western Libya. A not insignificant number of Geniza merchants hailed from Nafusa, but it is technically not a settlement location itself. Rather, the mountain is home to several towns and cities, most notably Zintan, Nalut, Jadu, Gharyan, Yefren, Kabaw, and others.

name: Pumbedita
notes: Home to one of the two major rabbinic academies in Iraq from late antiquity until the early 10th century when the academies moved to Baghdad.

name: Qaṣr al-Shamʿ (neighborhood)
notes: Neighborhood in Fustat.

name: Qujandīm
notes: Locality in al-Daqahliyya province; precise coordinates unknown.

name: Rafaḥ
notes: On the identification of Ḥaṣor as Rafaḥ, see M. A. Friedman, Jewish Marriage in Palestine, vol. 2, p. 316.

name: Raʾs Tīnī
notes: If identical with Raʿs al-Tīn, then it is a cape on the Libyan coast, west of Tobruk and located on the Gulf of Bomba. Observation posts were placed between here and Alexandria to spot ships' progress. Ships sailing west would stay close to the shore until this point and only thereafter cross blue water. (Information from Bramoullé, Les fatimides et la mer, 26)

name: Shamṭūniyya
notes: Unidentified location in Iraq; Goitein, Golb, and Gil each had different hypotheses.

name: Shaqqat al-Waʿr
notes: Unidentified port near Tobruk

name: Sicily
notes: Region

name: Sindābūr
notes: See Ranabir Chakravarti, "Candrapura/Sindabur and Gopakapattana: Two Ports on the West Coast of India (AD 1000–1300)," Proceedings of the Indian History Congress 60 (1999), 153–61.

name: Sinnūris
notes: For details on this village, see the references in Rapoport and Shahar, Villages of the Fayyūm, 159n207.

name: Soba
notes: Soba was the capital of the Nubian kingdom of Alodia (Arabic: ʿAlwa). Located on the banks of the Blue Nile, the town may have occupied an area of up to 275 ha, of which only ~1% has been excavated. The medieval city contained large houses, churches and monasteries. From the sixteenth century onward, however, it fell into ruin. Today the medieval remains are buried, but there is modern settlement in the area as a result of the expansion of nearby Khartoum. The site was excavated by the Polish Centre for Mediterranean Archaeology from 2019–22, and that team has published a number of reports and articles about the site. See the project page at: https://pcma.uw.edu.pl/en/2019/01/25/soba-2/

name: Sura
notes: Home to one of the two major rabbinic academies in Iraq from late antiquity until the early 10th century when the academies moved to Baghdad.

name: Sūsa (Libya)
name_variants: Apollonia, Sozusa, Sūsat Barqa, סוסת ברקה, سوسة برقة

name: Tārān
notes: Yāqūt (iii, 834) describes Tārān as an island in the Red Sea between the Gulf of Suez and the Gulf of ʿAqaba. It is a place with a whirlpool at the foot of a mountain, and it is the place where the winds from Egypt and Syria encounter each other, making it very dangerous to ships.

name: ואדי לינפש
notes: Unidentified location in Iberia, located "across the Tagus river. . . in the village of אלב̇יג̇ש." It is also possible to read the name as ואדי לעפש.

name: Wardūnyā
notes: A NW suburb of Baghdad. See N. Golb, ‘A Marriage Deed from ‘Warduniā of Baghdad,’ Journal of Near Eastern Studies 43.2 (1984), pp. 152–56.

name: Yemen
notes: Region
